The payment collected from a toll road is designed to keep roads in good repair. Road repair is essential to maintain the safety and quality of roads. Without regular maintenance, roads can become unsafe due to cracks, potholes, and other hazards. Tolls are primarily used to cover the costs associated with such repairs, along with other improvements and upgrades. 

The money collected from tolls helps fund the repair of roads, bridges, tunnels, and other infrastructure. In addition to these repairs, tolls can also be used to pay for new construction and expansion projects. Toll roads typically require higher levels of maintenance than non-toll roads, as they are often heavily used, leading to increased wear and tear. 

Toll roads are also beneficial for the environment. Tolls help reduce the number of vehicles on the road, resulting in fewer exhaust emissions and improved air quality. Additionally, proper maintenance of roads can reduce the amount of dust and other particles that are blown into the air due to road construction. This can help reduce health risks associated with air pollution.
